results.title: A Saucer of water for the birds
results.brief_description: The unusual technique of sand animation is used to tell the story of a woman and her granddaughter. It starts with them sitting at the kitchen table playing cards. As the cards are shuffled and cut, the film cuts between pre-war Poland, Europe in the Holocaust, the woman’s childhood and the present. The old woman’s homeland is evoked as a world the child strives to create from anecdotes. The woman’s present is shown as one etched with darkness of her family’s experience of the Holocaust.

results.title: His mother's voice
results.brief_description: Based on the transcript of an ABC radio interview, “His Mother’s Voice” is a powerful animated work which asks us to bear witness to the emotional force of tragedy. A mother recounts the details of learning about her son’s fatal shooting. We first hear her words while the images dramatise the events. We then listen to the words again as the animators focus our attention on her face, her moving lips, the boy’s bedroom and the activities of the suburban street on which he lived. The effect is equally mesmerising and devastating.

results.title: Food (for) thought
results.brief_description: Food. Religion. Television. Using a multiplicity of styles, this technically accomplished animation seeks to present a critique of religion and consumer culture. It makes an impressive idiosyncratic statement, with stylistic references to Jan Svankmajer and the Brothers Quay.

results.title: The Drive home
results.brief_description: Everyone wants to know how to find their perfect partner. A woman is driving home, listening to her car radio when the DJ announces a new theory on how to find your perfect partner. Only trouble is, the woman’s car is about to enter a tunnel. Will she ever discover the secret?

results.title: The Darra dogs
results.brief_description: Haunted by the dogs of his childhood, Dennis Tupicoff tries to explain his feelings about dogs to his 4 year old daughter. Dennis and his brothers grew up in Darra, then an industrial suburb of Brisbane where every household seemed to have a dog. Some were friends who shared their lives and explorations while others were “hounds from hell” prowling though the neighbourhood. The Darra Dogs is a memorial to the mortal terrors of childhood, the sadness of death and loss and, of course, to the dogs themselves.

results.title: Living inside
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and audio
results.brief_description: Sadie Benning, at the age of 16, dropped out of high school for three weeks and stayed inside with her camera, TV and a pile of dirty laundry. The result is an introspective work of stop and start edits, grainy images and Benning’s reflective commentary invoking a sense of isolation and sadness as she retreats from the outside world.

results.title: The Judy spots
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and audio
results.brief_description:
‘The Judy spots’ consists of five short videos featuring a papier-mache puppet called Judy. Clever, witty and extremely dark, each of the vignettes is a social commentary about human emotions and behavior.
The vignettes are: ‘Judy feels sad’, ‘Judy hates her job’, ‘Judy has a nightmare’, ‘Judy goes to the mall’ and ‘Judy gets mad’.
